questions.question:
Question 1: A 77-year-old woman presents with pain and limited movement of the left hip and knee for 10 
years. The pain has increased in severity in the past 1 year. The x-ray of the hip is given 
below. Laboratory tests do not show RF or ANA in her serum. Which of the following is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The x-ray image of the hip shows narrowing of the joint space and subchondral sclerosis which is 
diagnostic of osteoarthritis (OA), also called degenerative joint disease. OA is the most common type of joint disease, which is characterized by the degeneration of joint 
cartilage. This results in structural and functional failure of synovial joints. Osteoarthritis can be 
classified into 2 types: • Primary OA: Insidious onset, without apparent initiating cause, as an aging phenomenon • Secondary OA: Predisposing conditions such as joint deformity, a previous joint injury, or an 
underlying systemic disease such as diabetes, ochronosis, hemochromatosis, or marked obesity. The knees and hands are more commonly affected in women and the hips in men. OA lesions 
occur due to the degeneration of the articular cartilage and its disordered repair. Inflammatory 
cells are sparse, but cytokines and diffusible factors, particularly TGF- (which induces matrix 
metalloproteinases), TNF, prostaglandins, and nitric oxide, have been implicated in OA.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 28-year-old woman presents with complaints of joint pain and progressive loss of joint 
motion. On examination, symmetric joint swelling of the hands is seen. A subcutaneous 
nodule is seen over her right forearm. Microscopy of the excised nodule shows the findings 
given in the image below. Which of the following lab findings will be seen in this patient? 1239 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Uric acid crystals in joint aspirate
options.d: Calcium pyrophosphate crystals in joint aspirate

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The patient's serum will test 
positive for rheumatoid factor. Microscopy of the excised nodule shows a necrotizing granuloma with a central zone of fibrinoid 
necrosis surrounded by a prominent rim of activated macrophages and numerous lymphocytes 
and plasma cells. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of autoimmune origin that 
principally attacks the joints, producing nonsuppurative, proliferative, and inflammatory 
synovitis. The inflammation progresses to the destruction of the articular cartilage and ankylosis 
of the joints. In RA, the synovium contains germinal centers with secondary follicles and abundant plasma 
cells, which produce antibodies, some are autoantibodies. Many of the autoantibodies produced in 
the lymphoid organs are specific for citrullinated peptides (CCPs). 80% of patients have serum 
IgM or IgA autoantibodies that bind to the Fc portions of their own IgG. These autoantibodies are 
called rheumatoid factor and may also deposit in joints as immune complexes The characteristic histologic features of RA include: • Synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation • Dense inflammatory infiltrates • Increased vascularity due to angiogenesis • Fibrinopurulent exudate on the synovial and joint surfaces • Osteoclastic activity in underlying bone • Subcutaneous nodule: necrotizing granulomas with a central zone of fibrinoid necrosis 
surrounded activated macrophages, lymphocytes, and plasma cells 1247 
Sold by @itachibot This altogether leads to a mass of edematous synovium called pannus, which grows over the 
articular cartilage and causes its erosion.

questions.question:
Question 3: An obese 35-year-old man with renal failure presents with excruciating joint pain in the right 
knee. It is associated with localized hyperemia. Joint aspiration is done which shows dense 
neutrophilic infiltrate and the following finding under polarised light. Which of the following 
is the most likely diagnosis? 1240 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is gout. Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and 
crystals that are long, slender, needle-shaped, and negatively birefringent. Gout is marked by transient attacks of acute arthritis initiated by crystallization of monosodium 
urate (MSU) within and around joints. This results in the production of cytokines that recruit 
leukocytes. Macrophages phagocytose the MSU and the inflammasome activates caspase-1, which 
is involved in the production of some biologically active cytokines. The distinctive morphologic changes in gout are acute arthritis, chronic tophaceous arthritis, 
tophi in various sites, and gouty nephropathy. Tophi are the pathognomonic hallmark of gout. 
These are large aggregations of urate crystals surrounded by an intense inflammatory reaction of 
foreign body giant cells which may appear in the articular cartilage, ligaments, tendons, bursae, 
earlobes, fingertips, or kidneys. Gouty nephropathy refers to the renal complications caused by MSU crystals or tophi in the renal 
medullary interstitium or tubules. Complications include uric acid nephrolithiasis and 
pyelonephritis.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 3-year-old child with knee pain is found to have uric acid crystal deposition in his joints. On 
examination, excessive nail-biting is seen as shown below. Congenital deficiency of which of 
the following enzyme is responsible for this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. In this condition, there is a 
deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). Lesch–Nyhan syndrome is charecterised by neurological and behavioral abnormalities such as lip 
and finger biting and head banging. It also causes the overproduction of uric acid, leading to gouty arthritis and impaired kidney 
function. It is classified as secondary gout.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 50-year-old patient presents with left knee pain, redness, and swelling for 3 days. Joint 
aspiration is performed and microscopic findings under polarised light are given in the image 
below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 1241 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of calcium pyrophosphate crystal deposition disease 
(CPPD), also known as pseudo-gout and chondrocalcinosis. The image shows aspirated crystals which are rhomboid, 0.5 to 5 m in the greatest dimension, 
and positively birefringent (yellow). It usually occurs in individuals older than 50 years of age and becomes more common with old 
age. CPPD is classified into sporadic (idiopathic), hereditary, and secondary types. It is caused by 
germline mutations in the pyrophosphate transport channel. The secondary form is associated 1248 
Sold by @itachibot with • Previous joint damage • Hyperparathyroidism • Hemochromatosis • Hypomagnesemia • Hypothyroidism • Ochronosis • Diabetes Inflammation is usually milder than in gout. CPPD may produce acute, subacute, or chronic 
arthritis that can be confused with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis. The joint involvement 
may be monoarticular or polyarticular; the knees, followed by the wrists, elbows, shoulders, and 
ankles, are most commonly affected.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is not true about liposarcoma?

options.a: Amplification of 12q13-q15 is characteristic of well differentiated liposarcoma.
options.b: The key gene in the amplified region of chromosome 12q is MDM2.
options.c: The pleomorphic variant is usually indolent and rarely metastasizes.
options.d: Myxoid liposarcoma shows delicate 'chicken-wire' or 'crow’s feet' vasculature.

questions.explanation:
The pleomorphic variant of liposarcoma is usually aggressive and frequently metastasizes. Liposarcoma is one of the most common sarcomas of adulthood seen mainly in people in their 50s 
to 60s in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the retroperitoneum. Amplification of 12q13-q15 and t(12;16) are characteristic of well-differentiated and myxoid 
liposarcomas, respectively. One of the key genes in the amplified region of chromosome 12q is 
MDM2, which is a potent inhibitor of p53. Well-differentiated liposarcoma contains adipocytes with scattered atypical spindle cells. Myxoid 
liposarcoma contains an abundant basophilic extracellular matrix, arborizing capillaries 
(“chicken-wire” or “crow’s feet” vasculature), and primitive cells reminiscent of fetal fat. The well-differentiated variant is relatively indolent, while the myxoid/round cell type is 
intermediate in its malignant behavior.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 50-year-old man presented with a retroperitoneal mass. Biopsy from the lesion is shown in 
the image below. Molecular analysis revealed t(12;16). What is the most likely condition? 1242 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myxoid liposarcoma. The image shows abundant ground substance, with branching capillaries and a few immature 
adipocytes. Liposarcoma is the most common sarcoma in adults and is usually seen in the 5th to 6th decade 
of life. They commonly occur in the deep soft tissues of the proximal extremities and in the 
retroperitoneum. Histologically the liposarcomas are divided into three subtypes: • Well-differentiated liposarcoma: It consists of mature adipocytes and scattered spindle cells with 
hyperchromatic nuclei. It is associated with amplification of 12q13-q15. 1249 
Sold by @itachibot • Myxoid liposarcoma: It contains abundant basophilic extracellular matrix with branching 
capillaries. Few immature adipocytes are found scattered within the matrix. It is associated with 
t(12;16). • Pleomorphic liposarcoma: It consists of sheets of anaplastic cells with bizarre nuclei and few 
immature adipocytes. Among the three subtypes, the pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often 
metastasizes, while the well-differentiated is least malignant. Myxoid liposarcoma has 
intermediate malignancy behaviour.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 30-year-old man presented with a 2-cm, rapidly growing, painful, subcutaneous mass on 
his left arm. Microscopy revealed immature proliferation of fibroblasts and myofibroblasts 
with abundant mitotic figures. Immunohistochemistry was positive for vimentin and 
muscle-specific actin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nodular fasciitis. Nodular fasciitis is a self-limited fibroblastic and myofibroblastic proliferation that typically 
occurs in young adults in the upper extremity. Etiology is unclear but a history of trauma is 
present in approximately 25% of cases. The tumors grow rapidly over a period of several weeks, 
typically no larger than 3 cm. It typically regresses spontaneously and if excised, rarely recurs. Microscopically, it is richly cellular and contains plump, immature-appearing fibroblasts and 
myofibroblasts, arranged randomly or in short fascicles reminiscent of tissue culture fibroblasts. A 
gradient of maturation from cellular, loose, and myxoid to organized and fibrous is typical. The 
cells vary in size and shape (spindle to stellate) and have conspicuous nucleoli; mitotic figures are 
abundant. Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for vimentin, smooth muscle actin, and muscle-specific 
actin. Desmoid tumours are firm and poorly demarcated masses which infiltrate the surrounding 
muscle, nerve and fat. Histologically, fibroblasts are arranged in long parallel fascicles amid dense 
collagen. (Option 2) The image below shows the histopathological findings of nodular fasciitis. 1250 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A 40-year-old man presented with a swelling in the floor of his mouth for 6 months. Intraoral 
examination revealed a soft, painless, non-tender mass in the left floor of the mouth, 
extending posteriorly into the supraglottic region. On histopathological examination, spider 
cells were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rhabdomyomas. Rhabdomyoma is a benign neoplasm of skeletal muscle that mainly occurs in the head and neck 
region. Although the mass is usually asymptomatic, it may compress or displace the tongue or 
may cause partial obstruction of the pharynx. Rhabdomyomas can be classified into cardiac (most common) or extracardiac. Spider cells are seen in this condition. These are large, rounded, polygonal cells with glycogen 
vacuoles separated by strands of cytoplasm extending between the cell membrane and nucleus. The image given below shows spider cells.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 17-month-old girl presented with abnormal vaginal bleeding. A gynecological examination 
showed abnormal vaginal tissue protruding through the introitus. Histopathological analysis 
showed sheets of spindled cells in a myxoid stroma, which stained positive for desmin and 
Myo-D1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of sarcoma botryoids, which is a variant of embryonal 
rhabdomyosarcoma. It is a malignant mesenchymal tumor with skeletal muscle differentiation. Rhabdomyosarcomas are the common soft tissue sarcomas of childhood and adolescence, 
classified into four subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, pleomorphic, and spindle-shaped/ sclerosing. • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma: It contains sheets of both primitive round and spindled cells in 
a myxoid stroma. Sarcoma botryoids is a variant that occurs in the walls of hollow, mucosal-lined 
structures, such as the nasopharynx, common bile duct, bladder, and vagina. • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma: consists of the network of fibrous septae that divide the cells into 
clusters or aggregates, creating a crude resemblance to pulmonary alveoli. • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma - consists of large, sometimes multinucleated, bizarre 
eosinophilic tumor cells. 1251 
Sold by @itachibot • Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma - Consists of fusiform cells with vesicular chromatin 
arranged in long fascicles or in a storiform pattern. On immunohistochemistry, they are positive for desmin, myoglobin, myogenin, MyoD1, and 
vimentin. Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma is seen predominantly in adults. The botryoid variant of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma has the best prognosis, while the 
pleomorphic subtype is often fatal.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 26-year-old man presents with left knee pain for 6 months. MRI shows a 
well-circumscribed 4-cm mass superior to the patella within soft tissue. Biopsy shows a 
biphasic pattern of spindle cells and epithelial cells forming gland-like structures. Karyotype 
shows t(X,18) translocation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of synovial sarcoma. It can be present in locations (chest wall, head, and neck) that lack synovium. Most lesions occur 
in people in their 20s to 40s. Patients usually present with a deep-seated mass that has been 
present for several years. Most synovial sarcomas show a characteristic chromosomal translocation t(x;18)(p11;q11) 
producing SS18-SSX1, SS18-SSX2, or SS18-SSX4 fusion genes. They are morphologically classified into monophasic or biphasic: • Monophasic synovial sarcoma consists of uniform spindle cells with scant cytoplasm and dense 
chromatin growing, in short, tightly packed fascicles. • Biphasic type consists of a spindle cell component with gland-like structures composed of 
cuboidal to columnar epithelioid cells. Tumor cells, especially in the biphasic type, are positive for 
epithelial markers (e.g., keratins), differentiating them from most of the other sarcomas.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 13-year-old boy presents with fever, pain, and swelling in the left mid-thigh region. X-ray 
shows lamellated periosteal reaction resembling an onion skin. A biopsy from the lesion is 
shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 1244 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ewing's sarcoma. It is a malignant bone tumor that occurs primarily in children and young adults, in the age group 
of 10-20 years. It usually affects the long bones, such as the femur, tibia, or humerus. 
Occasionally, the tumor may begin in the muscles or soft tissues (extraosseous Ewing's sarcoma). Microscopically, solid sheets of small uniform round cells with PAS-positive magenta pink colored 
cytoplasm are characteristic of Ewing’s Sarcoma/PNET. The cells show PAS positivity due to the 
presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen. This is an important feature for the 
differential diagnosis of Ewing's with other small round cell tumors.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 36-year-old man with a history of blunt trauma to the left upper arm presents with swelling 
and redness 3 weeks later. There is a 4-cm mass in the outer aspect of the upper left arm in 
the soft tissue. Radiographs show a radiolucent center and surrounding irregular bone 
formation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myositis ossificans (MO). It is a pseudo-inflammatory tumor that originates from skeletal muscle and corresponds to a 
heterotopic, metaplastic, nonmalignant bone tumor. It is a highly inflammatory, rapidly growing, and painful muscular mass, which is seen following 
muscular trauma. The late stage is characterized by a typical zonal pattern (zonal phenomenon). It 
consists of three zones: • Innermost zone: made of proliferating fibroblasts and myofibroblasts with areas of hemorrhage 
and necrosis • Intermediate zone: contains osteoblasts with the immature osteoid formation • Peripheral zone: the mature bone

questions.question:
Question 15: An 18-months-old child is brought to you with complaints of fever with chills and right knee 
pain for 3 days. On examination, his knee is warm and swollen with localized erythema. Joint 
aspiration showed 60,000 /mm3 WBCs. Which of the following organisms is the most likely 
cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of septic arthritis. The most common organism implicated 
in this condition in children < 2 years is Staphylococcus aureus. Since the advent of the Haemophilus influenzae vaccine, the predominant causes of septic 
arthritis among children <5 years of age have been S. aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes (group A 
Streptococcus), and (in some centers) Kingella kingae. Causative organism of bacterial arthritis: Note: H. influenza arthritis predominates in children younger than 2 years of age, particularly in
